This case was filed on March 5, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas by the Texas A&M Queer Empowerment Council, a recognized student organization at Texas A&M University. The Council, represented by private counsel from the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE), brought suit against the members of the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents, the Chancellor, and the President of Texas A&M University, all in their official capacities.

The dispute arose after the Texas A&M Board of Regents held a special meeting on February 28, 2025, and adopted a resolution prohibiting “drag show events” on university campuses, explicitly targeting Draggieland, an annual student-organized and student-funded drag performance that had been scheduled for March 27, 2025, at the Rudder Theatre. The Board’s resolution cited its opposition to “gender ideology” and referenced a federal executive order and state government directives. Following this resolution, university officials canceled Draggieland and notified the Council that the event could not proceed on campus. The Queer Empowerment Council had already reserved the venue, sold tickets, and invested resources in preparing for the performance, which had previously been held successfully on campus for several years.

The Council alleged that this ban constituted viewpoint and content discrimination in violation of the First Amendment’s Free Speech Clause, as well as an impermissible prior restraint on protected expressive conduct. The Council also raised a claim under the Texas Open Meetings Act, asserting that the Board failed to provide adequate public notice for the meeting at which the drag show ban was adopted. The Council sought a temporary restraining order, a preliminary and permanent injunction to prevent enforcement of the ban, a declaratory judgment affirming its rights, and an order voiding the Board’s actions at the February 28 meeting.

The case was assigned to Senior Judge Lee H. Rosenthal. After expedited briefing and a hearing on March 18, 2025, the court granted the Council’s motion for a preliminary injunction on March 24, 2025. Judge Rosenthal found that Draggieland constitutes protected speech and expressive conduct under the First Amendment, that the Rudder Theatre functions as a designated public forum, and that the Board’s resolution was a viewpoint-based restriction and an unconstitutional prior restraint. The court ordered the defendants not to enforce the drag show ban and required that Draggieland be permitted to proceed as scheduled on March 27, 2025. The court further held that the Council was not required to post a bond for the injunction.

The defendants filed a notice of appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on March 28, 2025, and moved to stay the injunction pending appeal. As of the latest docket entries, the case remains stayed pending appellate proceedings.

No trial has been held, and there are no settlements or monitors appointed in this action. The only reported opinion to date is the district court’s memorandum and opinion at 2025 WL [number not provided], granting the preliminary injunction. The factual basis for the case centers on Texas A&M’s abrupt cancellation of a student drag performance based on the administration’s disapproval of its perceived message, despite longstanding university policies supporting student expressive activities in campus venues.

On March 31, 2025, a nonprofit financial intermediary for community development credit unions filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the EPA Administrator and Acting Deputy Administrator in their official capacities, and Citibank, N.A. The nonprofit is represented by private counsel. The case arises from the administration of the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF), a nearly $27 billion program created by Congress through the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 to support clean energy, energy efficiency, and pollution reduction through competitive grants.

The nonprofit received a $1.87 billion grant under the Clean Communities Investment Accelerator (CCIA) program, one of the three GGRF initiatives. Its grant agreement, memorialized on August 8, 2024, and modified December 19, 2024, authorized it to distribute funds to credit unions nationwide to finance clean energy projects, primarily in low- and moderate-income communities. Under the program structure, Citibank was appointed as a financial agent to hold and disburse grant funds at the nonprofit’s direction, subject to federal oversight.

After the nonprofit began implementing its grant and selected 108 credit unions for subawards, the EPA Administrator announced in February 2025 a freeze and intended clawback of all GGRF funds, citing concerns about program integrity and alignment with agency priorities. Citibank, acting on discussions and directives from government officials, subsequently refused to release the grant funds. On March 11, 2025, EPA issued a notice purporting to terminate all GGRF grants, including the nonprofit’s, referencing regulatory authority but providing only general allegations of fraud, waste, abuse, and lack of oversight, without citing specific misconduct by the nonprofit or affording the nonprofit an opportunity to contest the termination.

The nonprofit brings statutory and constitutional claims against the EPA and its officials, alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Inflation Reduction Act, the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, the Anti-Deficiency Act, and EPA’s own regulations. It asserts that the EPA's freeze and termination exceeded statutory authority, failed to comply with required procedures, were arbitrary and capricious, and violated the separation of powers, the Spending Clause, the Appropriations Clause, the Take Care Clause, and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. The nonprofit also alleges that Citibank breached its contractual duties under the Account Control Agreement by refusing to honor lawful disbursement instructions, and asserts claims for conversion and replevin.

The nonprofit seeks declaratory and injunctive relief, including orders invalidating the EPA’s termination, requiring EPA and Citibank to restore and release the grant funds, and barring further interference with the nonprofit’s access to its funds except as permitted by law. It also requests court orders requiring Citibank to comply with its contractual obligations regarding disbursement.

Shortly after filing, the nonprofit moved for a preliminary injunction and, when funds appeared to be removed from its Citibank account, for an emergency temporary restraining order. The case was assigned to Judge Tanya S. Chutkan and consolidated with related litigation (Case No. 25-cv-698) involving other GGRF grantees. As of April 16, 2025, the motion for preliminary injunction in this case was denied as moot in light of the preliminary injunction order in the lead consolidated case, with further proceedings to be governed under that lead case.

No trial has occurred, and no final decree or settlement has been entered as of the most recent docket entry. The factual basis of the case centers on the nonprofit’s reliance on its federal grant, the EPA’s subsequent suspension and attempted revocation of that grant, and the resulting inability of the nonprofit and its subrecipients to access congressionally appropriated clean energy funds.

This case was filed on April 11, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California by a group of international students and recent graduates, all in lawful F-1 visa status and residing or working in the district. The plaintiffs include current students and individuals employed under post-graduate Optional Practical Training (OPT). They are represented by private counsel from Van Der Hout LLP.

The defendants are the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the Acting Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the Acting Field Office Director of ICE in San Francisco, and the President of the United States, all sued in their official capacities.

The plaintiffs allege that, beginning in early April 2025, ICE abruptly and unlawfully terminated their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records, marking them as failing to maintain status due to criminal records checks or visa revocations. Plaintiffs assert that these terminations occurred without legal justification, proper notice, or opportunity to respond, and that none of them had committed any action or sustained any conviction that would render them ineligible for F-1 status or deportable. The complaint states that similar SEVIS terminations have affected hundreds of students nationwide, often accompanied by Department of State visa revocations.

The suit is brought under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–06, and the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–02. Plaintiffs assert that the SEVIS terminations were (1) unauthorized by statute or regulation, (2) arbitrary and capricious, (3) issued without required procedures, and (4) in violation of their Fifth Amendment procedural due process rights. The statutory context cited includes 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(15)(F)(i), 8 C.F.R. §§ 214.2(f), 214.1(d)-(g), and related regulations governing F-1 status. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including an order vacating the SEVIS terminations, restoring their status, and preventing enforcement actions such as arrest, detention, or deportation based on the challenged terminations.

The case was initially assigned to Judge Noël Wise, who granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) on April 17, 2025, enjoining the government for 14 days from arresting, detaining, transferring, or otherwise imposing legal consequences on the plaintiffs related to the SEVIS terminations or potential visa revocations. The order also required confidentiality for plaintiffs' identities. The TRO was later extended for an additional 14 days after a hearing on April 25, 2025, before Judge Jeffrey S. White, to whom the case was reassigned and who presides over related cases involving similar SEVIS terminations.

The court found that the plaintiffs demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits of their APA and due process claims, as well as a likelihood of irreparable harm, including loss of educational and employment opportunities and risk of detention or deportation. The court noted that the government’s actions appeared inconsistent with applicable regulations, which only permit SEVIS termination in limited circumstances not present here.

On May 22, 2025, Judge White granted a preliminary injunction, continuing to prohibit the government from taking enforcement action against the plaintiffs based on the disputed SEVIS terminations or related visa revocations, pending further proceedings. The case is set for further case management and remains pending. No settlement, final decree, or trial has occurred, and there is no indication of a court-appointed monitor. The defendants have appealed the preliminary injunction to the Ninth Circuit.

The factual basis of the case revolves around the government’s abrupt SEVIS terminations for international students and OPT participants based on alleged criminal records or visa revocations, despite the absence of disqualifying conduct or convictions, and the lack of required notice or process to the affected individuals. The court has consolidated related cases and required the government to explain its policies and procedures regarding SEVIS terminations.

Judge Jeffrey S. White (currently presiding; Judge Noël Wise issued initial TRO)

Related to Doe v. Trump et al., 25-cv-03140-JSW, and other cases involving similar SEVIS terminations

This action was filed on April 29, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB), its Board of Directors, and three individual board members (each acting in their official capacity), against the President of the United States, the Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel, the White House Presidential Personnel Office and its Director, and the United States Office of Management and Budget and its Director. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel from Saul Ewing LLP. The dispute did not involve a class action.

The plaintiffs’ suit arose after an April 28, 2025, email from the Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel, purporting to terminate three CPB board members effective immediately on behalf of the President. The CPB is a nonprofit corporation established by Congress under the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 (47 U.S.C. § 396), with explicit statutory protections intended to insulate it from government interference, including provisions specifying that CPB is not a federal agency, its board members are not federal officers or employees, and that no government actor may exercise direction or control over it.

Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the President lacked statutory or constitutional authority to remove CPB board members, and asserting violations of the Public Broadcasting Act, the Administrative Procedure Act, and multiple constitutional provisions, including the Separation of Powers, Presentment, Appropriations, and Take Care Clauses. They requested a declaration that the purported terminations were void and an order prohibiting further interference with the CPB’s governance.

The case was assigned to Judge Randolph D. Moss. Plaintiffs promptly moved for a temporary restraining order, which was treated as a motion for a preliminary injunction. The court held hearings and received briefing through May 2025.

In a memorandum opinion and order dated June 8, 2025 (2025 WL [not provided]), Judge Moss denied the request for preliminary injunctive relief. The court found that the plaintiffs had not established a likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable harm. The court concluded that, under District of Columbia nonprofit law—applicable to CPB unless inconsistent with the federal statute—the President, as the appointing authority, was permitted to remove board members unless the CPB’s bylaws or articles of incorporation provided otherwise. At the time of the removals, no such protective provisions existed, although the CPB subsequently amended its bylaws to require a two-thirds board vote for removal. The court further found that the statutory and bylaw framework allowed the CPB to protect its own independence and continue functioning, including through the use of a designated body if the board fell below a quorum.

The court did not resolve the ultimate legality of the removals or the plaintiffs’ claims for declaratory relief, leaving those questions for further proceedings. As of the latest docket entries, no trial had occurred, no final judgment had been issued, and no appeal had been filed. There were no consolidated or related cases formally joined, though the complaint referenced similar litigation involving the United States Institute of Peace. No settlement, monitor, or decree was reported.

The factual basis centered on the President’s attempt to remove CPB board members without statutory authority, the statutory structure of CPB as independent of executive control, and the potential harm to CPB’s operations and independence if such removals were effective. The case remained pending as of the most recent filings.

This case was filed on April 7, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia. The parties are a group of coal miners, represented as a class, led by an individual miner who developed black lung disease, against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its Secretary in their official capacities. The miners are represented by private counsel, including attorneys from Mountain State Justice, Inc., Appalachian Mountain Advocates, and Petsonk PLLC.

The case arises from HHS’s decision, effectuated on April 1, 2025, to terminate most employees of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health’s (NIOSH) Respiratory Health Division in Morgantown, West Virginia. This division had operated the Coal Workers’ Health Surveillance Program (CWHSP) and the “Part 90” job transfer program, which provide federally mandated medical screening for coal miners and the right to transfer to low-dust jobs if early signs of black lung disease (coal workers’ pneumoconiosis) are detected. The plaintiffs alleged that this closure made it impossible for miners to access statutorily guaranteed health screenings and transfer rights, thereby exposing them to ongoing hazardous dust and risk of disease progression.

The plaintiffs brought their claims as a class action under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23, on behalf of all coal miners nationwide eligible for Part 90 protections. They asserted causes of action under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706), the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause, and statutory provisions of the Coal Mine Health and Safety Act and the Mine Safety and Health Act (notably 30 U.S.C. § 843). Specifically, they alleged that HHS’s actions unlawfully withheld and unreasonably delayed agency action, were arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, and deprived miners of due process. The relief sought included declaratory and injunctive relief to restore the affected programs, class certification, and attorneys’ fees.

The case was assigned to Judge Irene C. Berger. The plaintiffs promptly moved for a preliminary injunction to restore the NIOSH Respiratory Health Division and its programs. The Court held a hearing on May 7, 2025, receiving testimony from miners, epidemiologists, and program coordinators, who described the essential, specialized work performed by CWHSP and the harm caused by its shutdown. The evidence showed that, without NIOSH, miners could not obtain the Part 90 letter necessary to enforce their workplace rights and that no other agency could provide comparable services.

On May 13, 2025, Judge Berger granted the preliminary injunction, finding a strong likelihood that the plaintiffs would succeed on the merits of their APA and due process claims. The Court concluded that the closure of the CWHSP was a final agency action that violated statutory mandates and caused irreparable harm to miners by denying them life-saving health protections. The injunction ordered HHS to rescind the reductions in force, fully restore the NIOSH Respiratory Health Division and its programs, and ensure no gap in services mandated by Congress. HHS was directed to certify compliance within 20 days. The order set the security required for the injunction at zero, due to the public interest and the likelihood of plaintiffs’ success. As of the latest docket entries, the case remains ongoing, with discovery and other proceedings scheduled, and no final judgment, settlement, or appeals reported. No court-appointed monitor was designated, and there are no reported opinions aside from the preliminary injunction order (2025 WL citation not assigned in the record). The factual basis for the case centers on the health risks faced by coal miners, the statutory framework protecting them, and the immediate harm resulting from the federal program’s closure.

This case was filed on May 17, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Central District of California. The action was brought by a Venezuelan national currently detained at a federal immigration facility in California, who also sought to represent a class of similarly situated noncitizens. The plaintiffs are individuals in federal immigration detention in the Central District of California, all subject or potentially subject to a March 2025 Presidential Proclamation—Proclamation No. 10903, entitled “Protecting the American People Against Invasion.” The defendants are federal government officials and agencies, including the President of the United States, the Attorney General, the Secretaries of Homeland Security, Defense, and State, and various immigration enforcement officials, all sued in their official capacities.

The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel. The case is not a class action in the traditional sense but was certified as a class for purposes of preliminary injunctive relief, specifically covering all noncitizens in custody in the Central District of California subject to the March 2025 Proclamation, with certain exclusions.

The primary cause of action is a petition for writ of habeas corpus, combined with requests for declaratory and injunctive relief. The core claims challenge the lawfulness of the Presidential Proclamation issued under the Alien Enemies Act (50 U.S.C. §§ 21 et seq.), which authorizes the immediate removal of certain Venezuelan nationals alleged to be associated with the Tren de Aragua organization. Plaintiffs allege constitutional violations, including due process violations under the Fifth Amendment, and seek to prevent removal without adequate notice and an opportunity to challenge removal.

Upon filing, the plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) and class certification. On May 19, 2025, Judge John W. Holcomb granted, in part, both applications. The court certified a class for the limited purpose of adjudicating what notice is due before removal under the Proclamation and issued a TRO enjoining the government from removing or transferring the named plaintiff or any class member pursuant to the Proclamation, pending further order. The court also ordered briefing and set a hearing on whether to convert the TRO into a preliminary injunction.

On June 2, 2025, the court issued an amended order granting, in part, preliminary injunctive relief. The court found that, while it could not review the President’s factual determinations under the Alien Enemies Act, it could and did order that due process requires adequate notice and an opportunity to be heard before removal. The preliminary injunction barred the government from removing or transferring any class member under the Proclamation without further order, and required the posting of a nominal $1 bond. The order clarified that it did not prevent the government from releasing detainees or removing them under other lawful processes, such as removal orders issued under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).

On June 20, 2025, the court denied the named plaintiff’s ex parte application for immediate habeas or mandamus relief seeking release after an immigration judge granted his asylum application. The court found that, because the government had appealed the asylum decision, the plaintiff’s detention pending resolution of that appeal was authorized by 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(2)(A), and thus habeas relief was not warranted at that time.

Throughout the proceedings, the court cited and followed recent higher court opinions addressing the same or similar executive actions under the Alien Enemies Act, including Supreme Court decisions clarifying the necessity of notice and due process before removal.

The case remains pending, with the government required to file periodic status reports regarding the status of the removal and asylum appeal. No final trial or judgment has occurred, and there is no reported opinion or appellate outcome yet for this specific case, though related litigation in other districts and at the Supreme Court has played a significant role in shaping the court’s rulings. There is no court-appointed monitor and no settlement has been reached. The court’s preliminary injunction remains in effect, preserving the status quo while the underlying legal questions about notice and process under the Proclamation are litigated.

This case was filed on May 22, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by the Register of Copyrights and Director of the U.S. Copyright Office. The plaintiff is represented by private counsel from the Democracy Forward Foundation and Munger, Tolles & Olson LLP. The defendants are the person designated by the President as acting Librarian of Congress, an individual designated as acting Register of Copyrights, the Director and Deputy Director of the White House Presidential Personnel Office, the Executive Office of the President, and the President of the United States, all sued in their official capacities.

The dispute arose after President Trump, on May 8, 2025, removed the Librarian of Congress, and, two days later, purported to remove the Register of Copyrights and to replace both positions with presidential appointees—actions the plaintiff contends were unauthorized. The plaintiff argues that only the Librarian of Congress, not the President, possesses statutory authority to appoint (and therefore remove) the Register of Copyrights, under 17 U.S.C. § 701(a). The plaintiff further contends that the President lacks authority, under the Appointments Clause and the Federal Vacancies Reform Act, to appoint an acting Librarian of Congress or to fill Copyright Office leadership positions, as the Library of Congress is not an executive agency.

The plaintiff brought claims for ultra vires action in violation of statutory and constitutional authority, and for violation of the Appointments Clause and the separation of powers, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent removal from office and to bar the defendants from interfering with her position. The remedies sought include preliminary and permanent injunctions restoring the plaintiff to her office, declarations on the limits of presidential appointment authority, and other appropriate relief.

Judge Timothy J. Kelly presided over the proceedings. The plaintiff first sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) and, after it was denied for lack of irreparable harm, moved for a preliminary injunction. The preliminary injunction was also denied on July 30, 2025 (see 2025 WL 4218003), with the court ruling that the plaintiff had not demonstrated a likelihood of irreparable harm from her temporary removal, as required for such extraordinary relief in government personnel cases. The court found that any harm suffered could be remedied if she prevailed on the merits and noted that neither the existence of the Copyright Office nor her position was threatened in a way that could not be reversed.

Following the denial of the preliminary injunction, the plaintiff appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on July 31, 2025. An emergency motion for an injunction pending appeal was filed and denied on August 20, 2025, for the same reasons as the prior rulings: the plaintiff failed to establish a risk of irreparable harm absent interim relief. As of the latest proceedings, briefing on cross-motions for summary judgment has been scheduled, and the case remains pending in district court while the appeal proceeds.

The factual basis for the case centers on the President’s removal of the Librarian of Congress and the Register of Copyrights, the subsequent attempt to install presidential appointees into those roles without congressional or statutory authorization, and the resulting dispute over the separation of powers and statutory interpretation concerning the governance of the Library of Congress and the Copyright Office. No trial has occurred, and there are no reported settlements, decrees, or court-appointed monitors. The case has not been consolidated with any other cases.

This case was filed on April 20, 2023, in the United States District Court for the District of Wyoming by two parents, one of whom is also a public school teacher, against the Sweetwater County School District No. 1 Board of Trustees and four district officials, including the superintendent, assistant superintendent, director of student services, and a high school principal. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel from Bailey Stock Harmon Cottam Lopez LLP and the Child & Parental Rights Campaign.

The plaintiffs are parents of a minor child, A.S., a student at Black Butte High School, as well as four other children in district schools. The mother, Ashley Willey, is also employed as a district teacher. The lawsuit is not a class action; it is brought by these individual plaintiffs.

The action arises from the school district’s implementation of a policy under which school staff, including the parent-teacher plaintiff, would use a student’s preferred name and pronouns at school if requested, even if this differed from the student’s legal name and sex, without informing the parents unless the student consented. The plaintiffs allege that, during the 2021-2022 school year, staff began treating their daughter as a boy at her request, using a male name and pronouns, while intentionally withholding this information from the plaintiffs, despite their daughter’s mental health history and ongoing treatment for trauma, ADHD, PTSD, and symptoms of gender dysphoria. The plaintiffs only discovered this practice by chance. The policy also required staff to use the student's legal name and pronouns when communicating with parents if the student did not want their parents informed, and threatened professional discipline for staff who did not comply.

The plaintiffs assert that this policy violates their fundamental parental rights to direct their children’s upbringing and mental health treatment under the Fourteenth Amendment’s Due Process Clause, their rights to free exercise of religion and free speech under the First Amendment, and state law requiring parental consent for mental health treatment. The mother further claims the policy forces her to violate her religious beliefs and compels her speech as a teacher. The main cause of action is brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as nominal and compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees.

The case was assigned to Judge Scott W. Skavdahl. No related or consolidated cases are noted.

Key filings include a motion for preliminary injunction by the plaintiffs and a motion to dismiss by the defendants. On June 30, 2023, Judge Skavdahl granted in part and denied in part the motion for preliminary injunction. The court enjoined the district from precluding employees from responding truthfully to a parent’s inquiry about a minor student’s requested name or pronoun, and from requiring employees to lie about such requests, except where there is a reasonable concern of physical abuse or harm. The motion was denied as to other aspects of the policy.

The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which was denied as moot after plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on July 20, 2023. Defendants again moved to dismiss the amended complaint. On December 18, 2023, the court granted in part and denied in part this motion: the plaintiffs’ claims for declaratory and injunctive relief under the first and second claims (parental rights and free exercise) were dismissed, but the plaintiffs were permitted to proceed on nominal and compensatory damages theories for those claims. The court also dismissed the free speech claim but allowed the mother’s claim for violation of her free exercise rights as a district employee to proceed.

The factual basis centers on the district’s policy to honor a student’s request to use alternate names and pronouns and to withhold this information from parents absent the student’s consent, even for students with known mental health challenges and ongoing treatment. The plaintiffs allege that this policy interfered with their ability to direct their child’s care, created psychological harm, and conflicted with their religious beliefs and rights as parents and as an employee.

As of the latest entries, the case proceeded through discovery and dispositive motions, and on April 28, 2025, the court granted summary judgment for the defendants on all remaining claims, dismissed the case, and entered final judgment. Plaintiffs have filed a notice of appeal to the Tenth Circuit. No settlement, decree, or court-appointed monitor is noted in the record. The court did not retain jurisdiction to enforce any settlement, as none was reached. There is no record of a trial; the case was resolved on summary judgment. 

All significant judicial decisions in the case are unreported orders, including the preliminary injunction order (6/30/23), order on motion to dismiss (12/18/23), and summary judgment order (4/28/25).

On April 14, 2022, the United States Department of Justice (“the United States”) filed a lawsuit against the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice (“the Department”) in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina, seeking to address unconstitutional conditions at the Broad River Road Complex (BRRC), the state's long-term facility for youth committed to the juvenile justice system. The United States was represented by the Department of Justice Civil Rights Division and the U.S. Attorney’s Office, while the Department was represented by private counsel.

The case arose from a multi-year federal investigation, initiated in 2017 under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 (34 U.S.C. § 12601), and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The investigation found reasonable cause to believe that the Department engaged in a pattern or practice of conduct at BRRC that violated the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause. Specifically, the government documented that the Department failed to keep children reasonably safe from youth-on-youth violence and excessive force by staff, used prolonged isolation for punitive purposes, and inadequately supervised and investigated incidents of harm.

The factual foundation included high rates of assaults and injuries among youth, frequent and prolonged use of isolation—even for minor misbehavior—dangerous and disproportionate use of force by staff (including physical abuse and restraint), and systemic failures in staff training, supervision, staffing levels, physical security measures, and incident investigations. Youth in isolation were often denied meaningful education and programming, sometimes leading to self-harm and deteriorating mental health. Investigations into abuse were often delayed, incomplete, or hampered by insufficient video coverage and documentation.

The United States sought declaratory and injunctive relief under 34 U.S.C. § 12601, requesting an order to prohibit the Department from continuing these practices and to require lawful conditions of confinement.

Shortly after the complaint was filed, the parties entered into a comprehensive, court-enforceable settlement agreement dated April 13, 2022, resolving all claims without further litigation. The agreement was jointly submitted to the court along with a motion for conditional dismissal, and Judge Mary Geiger Lewis granted the motion on April 20, 2022, dismissing the case without prejudice and retaining jurisdiction for enforcement.

Key terms of the settlement require the Department to: conduct a staffing study and adjust staffing patterns; enhance physical security and video surveillance; provide structured rehabilitative programming; establish and implement a positive behavior management system; sharply limit the use of force and isolation to situations involving serious and immediate danger; ensure prompt medical evaluation after uses of force; revise and enforce investigation policies for all incidents involving harm or improper isolation; ensure vulnerable youth are appropriately housed and not isolated for protective custody or suicide watch; and maintain robust quality assurance and data review systems. The President and federal officials also deployed approximately 700 Marines to Los Angeles.

The case alleged that the NYPD systematically conducted suspicionless stops, questioning, searches, citations, and arrests of residents and their invited guests in TAP buildings, often without individualized suspicion or probable cause, and that such practices disproportionately affected Black and Latino residents. The plaintiffs were represented by private and public interest counsel, including the New York Civil Liberties Union, Bronx Defenders, LatinoJustice PRLDEF, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, and Shearman & Sterling LLP.

The case was certified as a class action under Rule 23(b)(2), with the class defined as all individuals who have been or are at risk of being stopped, frisked, arrested, searched, or issued a summons inside or in the vicinity of TAP buildings without legal justification by NYPD officers on suspicion of trespassing.

A substantial factual record was developed, including a seven-day evidentiary hearing on the preliminary injunction motion, at which evidence was presented of widespread suspicionless stops, the impact on residents’ daily lives, and the disparate effects on communities of color. Plaintiffs presented expert analysis of NYPD data, testimony from individual class members, and evidence of the NYPD's policies and training.

The court ordered the NYPD to cease suspicionless stops for trespass outside TAP buildings in the Bronx and directed reforms to policies, training, supervision, and auditing. The court later certified the class and issued further remedial orders, including the appointment of an independent monitor, Peter L. Zimroth, to oversee implementation of reforms. The Hon. Ariel E. Belen was appointed as facilitator for a joint remedial process to solicit input from affected communities and stakeholders.

- Revising the Patrol Guide and administrative policies to clarify the legal standards for stops, questioning, frisks, searches, and arrests in and around TAP buildings.
- Specifying that mere presence in or around a TAP building is not grounds for a stop or arrest; requiring individualized suspicion.
- Mandating improved documentation for stops (including a new stop report form) and trespass arrests (with a new Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet).
- Implementing new training for all officers on the legal standards for stops, racial profiling, and TAP administration, with input from plaintiffs and the monitor.
- Establishing procedures for ongoing auditing, supervision, and discipline related to stops and trespass enforcement.
- Prohibiting racial profiling and requiring that enforcement actions not be motivated, even in part, by race, color, ethnicity, or national origin.
- Creating a process for community engagement in the development of further reforms.
- Providing monetary damages to named plaintiffs and agreeing to pay plaintiffs’ attorneys’ fees and costs.

On May 28, 2015, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit against the State of Alabama and the Alabama Department of Corrections (ADOC) alleging ongoing constitutional violations at the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women. The case was brought following a DOJ investigation, conducted under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, which uncovered pervasive and longstanding staff-on-inmate sexual abuse and harassment at Tutwiler. The DOJ found that women prisoners at Tutwiler endured rape, sexual assault, sexual harassment, and lived in a sexualized, threatening environment, with staff routinely engaging in and allowing sexual misconduct. The DOJ concluded that the State displayed deliberate indifference to these conditions, violating the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment.

The DOJ's investigation revealed that ADOC and Tutwiler officials had been aware of these problems for many years but failed to take effective action. Systemic deficiencies included inadequate policies, lack of staff training and supervision, absence of a grievance system, poor investigatory practices, retaliation against inmates who reported abuse, and dangerously low staffing levels. Prisoners were often compelled to submit to sexual advances to obtain basic necessities or to avoid punishment. The environment fostered underreporting of abuse and created significant barriers to inmate safety.

On the same day the complaint was filed, the parties submitted a joint motion for approval of a settlement agreement, which was entered as a consent decree by Judge Myron H. Thompson of the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama on June 18, 2015. The consent decree was court-enforced and required the State to implement a broad range of remedial measures. These included compliance with the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA), development and implementation of gender-responsive policies, establishment of confidential reporting and grievance mechanisms, adequate staffing (with a focus on recruiting female officers), staff training on PREA and gender-responsive practices, and ongoing monitoring and data collection to track progress and compliance.

The decree also established regular external monitoring. An independent monitor was appointed by joint agreement of the parties, and the court retained jurisdiction for enforcement. The monitor (initially Jennie Lancaster, later Kathleen Dennehy) conducted regular site visits, reviewed documents, interviewed staff and inmates, and issued detailed compliance reports assessing ADOC and Tutwiler’s adherence to the decree. These reports tracked progress, identified strengths, and outlined ongoing challenges, particularly relating to staffing shortages, physical plant limitations, and the need for sustained cultural change.

Remedial steps were phased, with deadlines for policy development, training, and implementation. The settlement addressed not only sexual abuse and harassment but also broader issues of staff accountability, data management, classification and discipline systems, access to medical and mental health care, and accommodations for vulnerable populations including LGBTI inmates and those with limited English proficiency.

Throughout the period of the consent decree, the court monitored compliance through regular status reports and hearings. The monitor’s reports documented significant improvements at Tutwiler, including new policies, enhanced training, creation of confidential reporting avenues, addition of cameras, and the launch of gender-responsive programming. However, challenges remained, particularly regarding persistent staffing shortages, facility overcrowding, and full implementation of gender-responsive classification and disciplinary systems.

The settlement agreement was court-enforced, with the court retaining jurisdiction for ongoing enforcement and dispute resolution. The State’s compliance was subject to review by the monitor and the court, and the case would remain open until the State demonstrated sustained, substantial compliance with all terms of the consent decree. The case is notable for its comprehensive approach to remedying systemic violations of women prisoners’ constitutional rights in a state prison setting, the collaborative resolution process, and the detailed, ongoing compliance monitoring framework.

On November 8, 2006, several civil rights organizations, labor unions, students, and prospective students (“the plaintiffs”) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan challenging the constitutionality of Michigan’s Proposal 2, a voter-enacted amendment to the state constitution (now Mich. Const. art. I, § 26). Proposal 2, approved by 58% of Michigan voters, prohibited public colleges and universities, as well as other public bodies, from granting “preferential treatment” or discriminating on the basis of race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public education, employment, or contracting. The plaintiffs, represented by private and nonprofit counsel (including Scheff & Washington, P.C., the ACLU, and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund), named as defendants the Governor of Michigan (in her official capacity), the governing boards of the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, Wayne State University, and other public educational institutions.

The plaintiffs alleged that Proposal 2 violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by restructuring the political process in a way that imposed special burdens on racial and gender minorities seeking race- or gender-conscious admissions policies. They also argued that Proposal 2 was preempted by federal civil rights statutes and violated First Amendment rights of the universities. The core factual basis for the claims was that, before Proposal 2, Michigan’s public universities could consider race as one factor in admissions, as upheld by the Supreme Court in Grutter v. Bollinger (2003). Proposal 2, however, removed the ability of university boards to adopt such policies, requiring any change to be made only through a statewide constitutional amendment, a process substantially more onerous than the ordinary political process available for other admissions criteria.

The case was assigned to Judge David M. Lawson. Early in the proceedings, the University defendants filed cross-claims and sought guidance on how to comply with the new amendment. The Michigan Attorney General intervened as a defendant to defend the constitutionality of Proposal 2. Additional parties and amici, including advocacy groups opposed to affirmative action and prospective students, attempted to intervene or participate.

In March 2008, after extensive briefing and discovery, Judge Lawson granted summary judgment for the defendants, holding that Proposal 2 did not violate the Equal Protection Clause, and dismissed all claims. The court concluded that the law did not impose an unconstitutional political restructuring under Hunter v. Erickson and Washington v. Seattle School District No. 1, reasoning that the amendment did not burden the right to “equal treatment” but rather restricted what the court characterized as “preferential treatment.”

The plaintiffs appealed. In July 2011, a panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed the district court, holding that Proposal 2 violated the Equal Protection Clause by restructuring the political process in a way that placed special burdens on minorities seeking to advocate for race-conscious admissions policies, thereby contravening Supreme Court precedent. The Sixth Circuit, sitting en banc, affirmed the panel’s decision in November 2012, ordering summary judgment for the plaintiffs.

The Michigan Attorney General petitioned for certiorari to the U.S. Supreme Court. The Sixth Circuit stayed issuance of its mandate pending Supreme Court review. On April 22, 2014, the Supreme Court reversed the Sixth Circuit in Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, 572 U.S. 291 (2014). The plurality opinion (Justice Kennedy) held that there was no authority in the U.S. Constitution or Supreme Court precedent for the federal courts to set aside a law that committed to voters the decision whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, including school admissions. The Court distinguished earlier political-process equal protection cases, finding that Michigan’s amendment was not enacted to inflict specific injury on a racial minority and did not violate the Equal Protection Clause. The Supreme Court’s judgment reinstated Michigan’s constitutional ban on race-based preferences in public university admissions.

**Key Information Checklist:**
- **Filing Date:** November 8, 2006
- **Parties:** Plaintiffs: civil rights organizations, labor unions, students, prospective students; Defendants: Michigan Governor (official capacity), University of Michigan Regents, Michigan State University Board of Trustees, Wayne State University Board of Governors, other public educational institutions.
- **Type of Plaintiffs:** Organizational and individual (not a class action per se; motions for class certification denied as moot)
- **Type of Counsel:** Private and nonprofit (Scheff & Washington, ACLU, NAACP Legal Defense Fund)
- **Cause of Action:** 42 U.S.C. § 1983; Equal Protection Clause (Fourteenth Amendment); other federal statutes
- **Statutory/Constitutional Basis:** Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause; Title VI and Title IX of the Civil Rights Act; First Amendment
- **Remedy Sought:** Declaratory and injunctive relief against enforcement of Proposal 2
- **Judge:** District Judge David M. Lawson
- **Important Filings:** Motions for summary judgment, motions to dismiss
- **Court Rulings:** District court—summary judgment for defendants, dismissed all claims; Sixth Circuit—reversed, found for plaintiffs (panel and en banc); Supreme Court—reversed Sixth Circuit, upheld Proposal 2
- **Reported Opinions:** 539 F. Supp. 2d 924 (E.D. Mich. 2008); 652 F.3d 607 (6th Cir. 2011); 701 F.3d 466 (6th Cir. 2012) (en banc); 572 U.S. 291 (2014) (Supreme Court)
- **Appeals:** To Sixth Circuit and U.S. Supreme Court
- **Context/Factual Basis:** Proposal 2 ended the ability of public universities to consider race in admissions; opponents argued this imposed special burdens on minorities under the political process doctrine.

No settlements, decrees, or monitoring were ordered, as the Supreme Court’s decision was dispositive.

On August 22, 2005, Maurizio Antoninetti, a wheelchair user, filed suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California against Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and related California statutes arising from his experiences at two newly constructed Chipotle restaurants in San Diego and Encinitas, California. Antoninetti, represented by private counsel, claimed that architectural barriers—including a 45-inch-high wall separating the customer line from the food preparation area—prevented individuals in wheelchairs from viewing the food on display and the preparation process, thereby denying them the “Chipotle experience” and full and equal enjoyment of the restaurant’s goods and services as required by the ADA.

During discovery and at trial, it was established that, although Chipotle had an unwritten policy to accommodate customers with disabilities, such as offering to show food samples or describing ingredients, Antoninetti and other wheelchair users could not independently see the food or watch the preparation as standing customers could. In February 2007, after the lawsuit was filed and during the course of litigation, Chipotle adopted a written “Customers with Disabilities Policy,” formalizing its accommodation practices.

After a bench trial before Judge Napoleon A. Jones, Jr., the district court found that Chipotle’s pre-litigation unwritten policy did not provide equivalent facilitation under the ADA, but that its written policy did comply with the Act. The court awarded Antoninetti $5,000 in statutory damages under the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA) for five “bona fide” visits to the restaurants as a customer, denied damages for three “litigation-related” visits, and denied injunctive relief. The court also awarded Antoninetti a reduced amount of attorneys’ fees, reflecting what it characterized as his limited success.

Antoninetti appealed, and Chipotle cross-appealed. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed in part, holding that Chipotle’s written policy did not provide “equivalent facilitation” as mandated by ADA Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) § 7.2(2)(iii), because it did not afford substantially equivalent access to the food preparation area as enjoyed by non-disabled customers. The appellate court held that the ADA required wheelchair users to have an experience comparable to that of other customers and that mere staff assistance or alternative methods were insufficient if the physical design itself remained inaccessible. The Ninth Circuit remanded with instructions to enter judgment for Antoninetti on the ADA claims, to craft appropriate injunctive relief to remedy the architectural barrier, and to reconsider the damages and attorney’s fee awards in light of Antoninetti’s greater success.

On remand, the district court entered judgment for Antoninetti, but declined to award injunctive relief because Antoninetti had died and his estate lacked standing for prospective relief. The court reaffirmed the $5,000 damages award for five customer visits, denied damages for the litigation-related visits, and ultimately awarded more than $545,000 in attorneys’ fees and costs to Antoninetti’s counsel, reflecting the protracted and complex nature of the litigation, the significance of the ADA violation, and the public benefit achieved by the ruling.

Throughout the proceedings, Chipotle was represented by private counsel, and Antoninetti by Amy B. Vandeveld and others. The case was presided over at the district court by Judge Napoleon A. Jones, Jr., and then Judge Barry Ted Moskowitz on remand; on appeal, the principal opinion was authored by Judge Daniel M. Friedman of the Ninth Circuit. The litigation resulted in a published Ninth Circuit opinion (643 F.3d 1165), which clarified the responsibilities of public accommodations under the ADA for newly constructed facilities, emphasizing that written or unwritten policies are not a substitute for physical accessibility. The court’s orders and judgments also resolved issues regarding prevailing party status, fee awards, and the appropriate calculation of damages under California law. The case is now closed, with a final amended judgment entered in favor of Antoninetti’s estate and against Chipotle for both damages and attorneys’ fees and costs.

On June 28, 2019, a group of individuals with prior felony convictions, along with several civil rights organizations, filed federal lawsuits in the Northern District of Florida against the State of Florida, the Secretary of State, the Governor, and several county Supervisors of Elections. The plaintiffs challenged Florida’s implementation of Amendment 4, a 2018 constitutional amendment that restored voting rights to individuals with felony convictions (excluding those convicted of murder or felony sexual offenses) upon “completion of all terms of sentence including parole or probation.” The lawsuits were filed as class actions, with the plaintiffs represented by counsel from the American Civil Liberties Union, NAACP Legal Defense Fund, Campaign Legal Center, Southern Poverty Law Center, and private attorneys.

After Amendment 4 was passed, the Florida Legislature enacted Senate Bill 7066 (SB 7066), defining “all terms of sentence” to include full payment of all court-ordered fines, fees, costs, and restitution—collectively known as legal financial obligations (LFOs)—even if they had been converted to civil liens. The plaintiffs alleged that conditioning restoration of voting rights on payment of LFOs violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Due Process Clause, and the Twenty-Fourth Amendment’s prohibition on poll taxes. They also challenged the administration of the law as unconstitutionally vague and sought relief under the National Voter Registration Act.

Judge Robert L. Hinkle presided over the consolidated cases. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief allowing otherwise eligible citizens to vote without regard to unpaid LFOs or, at a minimum, if they were genuinely unable to pay. Early in the litigation, the district court issued a preliminary injunction, later affirmed by the Eleventh Circuit (Jones v. Governor of Florida, 950 F.3d 795), holding that Florida could not deny the right to vote to individuals genuinely unable to pay their LFOs.

After an eight-day bench trial, Judge Hinkle issued a May 2020 order finding that the overwhelming majority of affected felons were indigent, that Florida’s system for determining and collecting LFOs was administratively unworkable, and that many individuals could not determine the amounts owed. The court held that the pay-to-vote system violated the Fourteenth Amendment as applied to those unable to pay, the Due Process Clause (due to lack of notice and procedures), and the Twenty-Fourth Amendment with respect to fees and costs constituting taxes. The court certified both a class and subclass and issued a permanent injunction requiring the State to implement an advisory opinion process for individuals uncertain about their LFO status, and to allow voting for those unable to pay or whose LFOs could not be determined.

On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit, sitting en banc, reversed the district court. The appellate court held that the requirement to pay outstanding LFOs before regaining voting rights did not violate the Constitution, applying rational basis review and concluding that the system was rationally related to Florida’s interests in punishment and rehabilitation. The court rejected heightened scrutiny under Griffin and Bearden, held that the Twenty-Fourth Amendment was not violated because the fees and costs were not “taxes” under its definition, and found no denial of due process or unconstitutional vagueness in the procedures. The court vacated the injunction, thus upholding Florida’s LFO payment requirement for voting rights restoration. The Supreme Court denied an application to vacate the stay, leaving the Eleventh Circuit’s decision in place.

The litigation arose from a context in which over a million Floridians with past felony convictions stood to regain voting rights, but the inclusion of LFO payment as a prerequisite was found by the district court to exclude the vast majority due to indigency and administrative barriers. The case involved significant filings: multiple complaints, class certification, preliminary and permanent injunctions, and appeals. A class was certified for those otherwise eligible to vote but for unpaid LFOs, and a subclass for those unable to pay. No settlement or monitor was involved. The case concluded with the Eleventh Circuit’s September 2020 opinion reversing the district court and vacating the injunction, effectively reinstating Florida’s pay-to-vote system for individuals with past felony convictions.

On July 18, 2002, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Central District of California on behalf of children in California’s foster care system, or at imminent risk of foster care placement, who have a mental illness or condition necessitating individualized mental health services. The case was brought against the directors of the California Department of Health Services and the Department of Social Services, as well as Los Angeles County and related officials, by a group of children represented by their next friends. Plaintiffs were represented by a coalition of private counsel, legal services organizations, and public interest groups, including the ACLU, Western Center on Law and Poverty, and Protection & Advocacy, Inc.

The plaintiffs alleged that the State and County failed to provide legally mandated mental health, behavioral support, and case management services to children in foster care or at risk of entering it. The complaint asserted violations of the Medicaid Act’s Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions (42 U.S.C. § 1396a et seq.), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, the Due Process Clauses of the United States and California Constitutions, and California Government Code § 11135. The requested remedies included declaratory and injunctive relief to require the provision of necessary services.

On June 18, 2003, the court certified a statewide class defined as children in California who (a) are in foster care or at imminent risk of foster care placement, (b) have a documented or documentable mental illness or condition, and (c) need individualized mental health services in the home or a home-like setting. A subclass comprised children with more intensive needs, such as those placed in or at risk of group homes, psychiatric hospitals, or multiple failed placements.

The Los Angeles County defendants entered into a court-approved settlement (the "County Settlement") in July 2003, which required systemic reforms overseen by an advisory panel and subject to ongoing court jurisdiction. The statewide claims against the State defendants continued, with the district court issuing a preliminary injunction in 2006 requiring California to provide intensive, community-based mental health services—such as wraparound services and therapeutic foster care—as medically necessary, under the Medicaid EPSDT mandate. The Ninth Circuit reversed the preliminary injunction in 2007, holding that while the State must provide all EPSDT-mandated component services, it was not required to provide them as a bundled "program" unless necessary for effective delivery.

After extensive negotiations facilitated by a Special Master, the parties reached a class-wide settlement in 2011. The settlement agreement, preliminarily approved in September 2011 and finally approved on December 5, 2011, required California to:

- Develop and implement a "Core Practice Model" for the delivery of coordinated, comprehensive mental health services to class members.
- Ensure the availability of Intensive Care Coordination (ICC), Intensive Home-Based Services (IHBS), and Therapeutic Foster Care (TFC) for children with intensive needs, statewide, as medically necessary under Medi-Cal.
- Amend the Medi-Cal State Plan and provider documentation to cover the necessary services.
- Establish shared management and quality oversight structures between the state agencies responsible for health and child welfare.
- Monitor compliance through a Special Master, an Advisory Panel, regular reports, data collection, and outcome evaluation.

The settlement was court-enforced, with jurisdiction set for 36 months, during which the Special Master and Advisory Panel regularly reported to the court on implementation. The court retained authority to enforce the agreement, resolve disputes, and award attorney’s fees (ultimately approved at $3.75 million).

With the expiration of court jurisdiction in December 2014, the parties agreed to maintain communication and continue implementation and monitoring. Subsequent reports by the Advisory Panel have documented ongoing progress and challenges, including improvements in staffing, team-based planning, and service delivery, but also persistent difficulties in consistently providing timely, intensive, individualized mental health services, ensuring placement stability, and achieving high-quality practice across the system.

As of the latest reports, the Advisory Panel has commended progress in some areas but has noted that many class members still do not receive the level of mental health services required under the settlement and federal law. The panel has continued to make recommendations for further improvements in service responsiveness and data collection. Court oversight has formally ended, but the parties, state agencies, and counties continue to be guided by the terms of the settlement and ongoing monitoring by the Advisory Panel.

On December 19, 2014, a Virginia prison inmate filed a civil rights action in the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, challenging the Virginia Department of Corrections’ (VDOC) policies and practices regarding long-term solitary confinement, specifically at Red Onion State Prison. The case was brought by an individual prisoner, proceeding pro se, against the VDOC and a range of supervisory officials and prison staff, including the VDOC Director and Red Onion’s wardens and managers. The inmate was later represented by pro bono counsel on appeal. The defendants were represented by the Office of the Attorney General of Virginia. The claims were not brought as a class action.

The plaintiff alleged that, following a 2009 incident involving a non-fatal stabbing of a guard, he was placed in solitary confinement—known as administrative segregation—where he remained for over eight years, with expectations of continued segregation for the remainder of his sentence, ending in 2040. He challenged VDOC’s administrative classification and review procedures under Operating Procedure (OP) 830.A, which governs the “Step-Down Program” for prisoners in segregation.

The plaintiff, classified as “Intensive Management” (IM) rather than “Special Management” (SM), argued that IM prisoners are permanently ineligible for the Step-Down Program that allows for return to the general population, regardless of their current behavior or risk. He claimed this resulted in indefinite, harsh solitary confinement without meaningful opportunity for release, in violation of his rights under the Eighth Amendment (cruel and unusual punishment) and the Fourteenth Amendment (procedural due process). He sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as compensatory and punitive damages.

The action was brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. The constitutional bases of the claims were the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment and the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantee of procedural due process.

The matter was assigned to Judge James P. Jones, with pretrial matters handled by Magistrate Judge Robert S. Ballou. No related or consolidated cases were noted in the record.

Key filings included motions to dismiss (under Rule 12(b)(6)), which were denied, and motions for summary judgment filed by the defendants, which the court ordered prior to the close of discovery. The plaintiff’s requests for class certification and appointment of counsel were denied. Discovery disputes arose regarding interrogatories, but the court granted the defendants’ request to delay responses until after the motion to dismiss was resolved.

On September 28, 2016, the district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants and dismissed the VDOC as a defendant. The court found that, although the plaintiff’s segregation was lengthy and restrictive, VDOC’s policy provided for periodic review and the opportunity for improved conditions based on behavior—thus, it did not implicate a protected liberty interest or amount to cruel and unusual punishment. The court ruled that the Step-Down Program offered a pathway to less restrictive conditions, and that the plaintiff had not demonstrated the deprivation of a basic human need, or deliberate indifference by prison officials.

The plaintiff, now represented by pro bono counsel, appealed to the Fourth Circuit (No. 16-7358), arguing that summary judgment was premature and that genuine disputes of material fact existed as to both his procedural due process and Eighth Amendment claims. Amici briefs from correctional and mental health experts supported the plaintiff, emphasizing the psychological and physical harms of prolonged solitary confinement and the lack of meaningful review under VDOC’s system.

On November 22, 2017, the Fourth Circuit affirmed the district court’s judgment in an unpublished per curiam opinion. The appellate court adopted the district court’s reasoning, holding that there was no reversible error in the grant of summary judgment to the defendants.

**Judge Information:**  
- District Judge: James P. Jones  
- Magistrate Judge: Robert S. Ballou  
- Appellate Panel: Judges Niemeyer, King, and Floyd (Fourth Circuit)

**Type of Counsel:**  
- Plaintiff: Pro se in district court; pro bono counsel on appeal  
- Defendants: Virginia Office of the Attorney General

**Important Filings and Outcomes:**  
- Motion to Dismiss: Denied  
- Motion for Summary Judgment: Granted for defendants  
- All claims against VDOC dismissed as legally frivolous  
- No trial was held  
- No decrees or settlements issued  
- Judgment for defendants, affirmed on appeal

**Remedy Sought:**  
- Declaratory and injunctive relief, compensatory and punitive damages

**Factual Basis of Case:**  
- Prisoner subjected to long-term solitary confinement after a 2009 assault  
- Challenged indefinite and harsh segregation under VDOC policy  
- Alleged lack of meaningful review and resulting mental and physical harms

**Appeals:**  
- Fourth Circuit: Affirmed summary judgment for defendants (Nov. 22, 2017; unpublished)

**Monitoring/Decree/Settlement:**  
- Not applicable; no ongoing decree, settlement, or court-appointed monitor.  

**Duration:**  
- No court-ordered decree or settlement; case closed with affirmance on appeal.

**Summary:**  
The case establishes that, under current Fourth Circuit precedent, the VDOC’s segregation and Step-Down procedures for long-term solitary confinement did not violate the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendments, as the procedures were found to provide for periodic review and opportunities for less restrictive conditions, and the restrictive conditions themselves were not found to be so severe as to amount to a constitutional violation. The judgment for the defendants was affirmed on appeal, and the case is now closed.

On January 19, 2006, a death-sentenced Maryland prisoner filed suit in federal district court seeking to enjoin his execution by lethal injection under the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services’ existing protocols. The plaintiff, represented by private counsel and legal services organizations, challenged the state’s lethal injection procedures under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging that the Department’s practices violated his Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by creating a substantial risk of unnecessary pain and suffering. The plaintiff did not contest the fact of his death sentence or the constitutionality of lethal injection per se, but argued that the State’s specific practices—such as the three-drug cocktail, lack of qualified personnel, and inadequate procedural safeguards—posed an unconstitutional risk of a torturous execution. He sought a declaratory judgment and an injunction prohibiting execution using the existing protocol, as well as other equitable relief.

The federal district court case named as defendants the Secretary of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Commissioner of the Division of Correction, the wardens of the Maryland Correctional Adjustment Center and the Metropolitan Transition Center, and unknown individuals involved in executions. The State was represented by the Maryland Attorney General’s office.

The plaintiff’s claims relied on 42 U.S.C. § 1983 as the cause of action, and were grounded in the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment, as incorporated by the Fourteenth Amendment. He alleged that the protocol’s use of sodium pentothal, pancuronium bromide, and potassium chloride, together with inadequate staff training and execution procedures, risked that prisoners would remain conscious and suffer excruciating pain during execution. He further argued that the protocol was not adopted in compliance with Maryland’s Administrative Procedure Act, and that its practices were inconsistent with Maryland law governing executions. The plaintiff sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory judgment, and attorneys’ fees.

After expedited proceedings—including a hearing on requests for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction—Judge Benson Everett Legg denied the request for preliminary relief, finding that the plaintiff had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits or a substantial risk of unconstitutional pain. The court noted that the protocol, if properly administered, would result in a swift and humane death, and that the plaintiff had not demonstrated a compelling constitutional deficiency in the protocol as applied. The court also found that the plaintiff had sufficiently exhausted administrative remedies or that further exhaustion would be futile given the timing of the execution.

The plaintiff appealed to the Fourth Circuit, which denied his emergency motion for an injunction pending appeal. The appeal was later dismissed at the plaintiff’s request after the Maryland Court of Appeals stayed the execution to resolve related state law challenges.

In parallel, the plaintiff and advocacy organizations pursued state court litigation challenging the protocol under state law and the Maryland Administrative Procedure Act. In December 2006, the Maryland Court of Appeals held that the lethal injection protocol constituted a regulation under state law and was therefore invalid until properly adopted in accordance with the state Administrative Procedure Act. The court enjoined executions under the old protocol until compliance, but rejected the plaintiff’s other constitutional and statutory challenges.

As a result of the Court of Appeals’ ruling, Maryland executions were suspended. The parties in the federal suit agreed to stay the case during ongoing legislative and administrative developments. Status reports were filed for several years, reflecting that Maryland had not adopted a new, valid execution protocol. In 2012, the parties requested and the court ordered the case administratively closed, with leave to reopen for good cause.

Throughout the proceedings, no trial was held, and the federal court did not issue any decree or substantive order requiring the State to change its execution protocol. The case was ultimately mooted by the state court’s action and legislative developments. The litigation’s main effect was to contribute to the judicial review and administrative suspension of Maryland’s prior lethal injection protocol, and to place executions on hold until a valid protocol could be adopted—a development that never occurred before Maryland abolished the death penalty in 2013.

- **Filing Date:** January 19, 2006 (federal court)
- **Parties:** The plaintiff was a Maryland death-sentenced prisoner; defendants were the Secretary of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Commissioner of Correction, two wardens, and unknown execution team members (all sued in their official capacities).

- **Remedy Sought:** Declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, attorneys’ fees

- **Important Filings:** Motions for TRO and preliminary injunction, motion to dismiss, motions to stay, status reports
- **Court Rulings:** Preliminary injunction denied; motion to dismiss denied after exhaustion; case stayed and administratively closed

Plaintiffs, represented by private counsel from Children’s Rights and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), alleged systematic failures by the District's child welfare agencies in providing required services and protections. The claims were based on 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of federal statutes (notably the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 and the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act), District of Columbia statutes (including the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977 and the Youth Residential Facilities Licensure Act of 1986), and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to remedy ongoing violations, including failures to investigate reports of abuse/neglect, provide services to avoid family separation, ensure timely and appropriate foster and adoptive placements, develop written case plans, and provide adequate oversight.

Following a bench trial in early 1991, Judge Thomas F. Hogan found the District in widespread violation of federal and local law, as well as the Constitution for children in its custody, and issued a detailed memorandum opinion. The court found that the child welfare system was plagued by excessive staff shortages, high caseloads, failure to investigate reports of abuse and neglect in a timely manner, failure to provide preventive and reunification services, inappropriate and unstable placements for children, lack of timely permanency planning, and systemic management deficiencies. The court held the District liable under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and ordered comprehensive injunctive relief.

A remedial order was entered with the agreement of the parties in August 1991, and the court certified the case as a class action pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2). The consent judgment established specific requirements for the District's child welfare system, including timelines and standards for investigations, services, placements, permanency planning, and reviews. The court appointed the Center for the Study of Social Policy as monitor to oversee compliance and report to the court.

Throughout the 1990s, the District was found repeatedly to be in noncompliance with the consent judgment and subsequent implementation plans. After persistent failures, the court imposed a limited receivership in 1994, followed by a full receivership in 1995. The court-appointed receiver and monitor exercised broad authority to implement reforms. Various progress reports, implementation plans, and corrective action plans were developed, tracking the District's compliance and management of the system.

The case underwent several appeals, with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit upholding the District's obligation to comply with the local law-based remedial orders and confirming the district court's authority to enforce consent decrees. The court clarified that even in the absence of ongoing federal law violations, the consent decree could be enforced on the basis of local statute.

After years of court oversight, the receivership ended in 2001 and was replaced by a probationary period, then by a series of court-approved implementation plans (2003, 2007, 2010), which set out detailed outcome measures, performance benchmarks, and monitoring requirements covering all aspects of child protection and foster care. The court retained jurisdiction, and the monitor continued to file regular reports on the District's progress, with further consent orders specifying corrective actions, sanctions for noncompliance, and attorneys’ fee settlements.

Despite significant progress, the District was found in contempt in 2010 for failing to comply with certain requirements. The court imposed compensatory remedies and required further detailed implementation and exit plans. In 2019, after mediation and negotiation, the parties jointly submitted an Exit and Sustainability Plan, approved by the court, which replaced the prior Implementation and Exit Plan. The Exit and Sustainability Plan removed from court monitoring those standards that the District had met and maintained, and established a process and commitments for the District to achieve the remaining outcomes, with continued monitoring and public reporting. The plan provides for eventual termination of court supervision upon demonstration of sustained compliance.

Throughout the case, the court has periodically awarded attorneys’ fees and costs to plaintiffs’ counsel by consent, and the monitor has played a central role in tracking compliance, reporting data, and facilitating improvements in the District’s child welfare system. As of the last filings, the case remains under court jurisdiction, with the Exit and Sustainability Plan guiding the final steps toward full compliance and exit from court oversight.
